Parameter.description: The property of your configuration. The library will resolve your key as object path. If the key containing a ".", you must pass an String[] to enforce your customized path traversal. You must specify a key(path) to delete one property. If you would like to delete the whole document, use DeleteDocument()
The options to this delete configuration request
The core configuration lambda function name
The dynamoDB table name to store all configurations
The document name to delete the configuration
Does the library directly delete config from dynamoDB or though aws-lambda-configuration-core

examples.title: delete-single-config(js/promise)
delete-single-config(ts/async-await)
examples.content: await config1.delete('version');

Parameter.description: The name of your configuration. You must specify the documentName. Default value is not applicable here. If you would like to delete only one property in a document, use delete()
The options to this delete configuration request
The core configuration lambda function name
The DynamoDB table name to store all configurations
Does the library directly access dynamoDB or though aws-lambda-configuration-core

examples.title: delete-whole-config(js/promise)
delete-whole-config(ts/async-await)
examples.content: await config1.deleteDocument('version');

title: decryptKEK
name: decrypt_KEK_data
description: Decrypt the data by Key-encryption-key (KEK). This function will decrypt your data by your data key which is encrypted by your AWS cmk.

Parameter.description: The data to be decrypted
A base 64 encoded cipher of encrypted data
A base 64 encoded of key-encrypted-key

examples.title: decryptKEK(js/promise)
decryptKEK(ts/async-promise)

Success 200.description: The data you encrypted, in exactly same format of what you pass into encryptKEK()

title: decrypt
name: decrypt_config
description: Decrypt the data directly though AWS KMS

Parameter.description: The encrypted cipher generated by encrypt()

examples.title: decrypt(js/promise)
decrypt(ts/async-await)

Success 200.description: The data you encrypted, in exactly same format of what you pass into encrypt()

title: encryptKEK
name: encrypt_KEK_data
description: Encrypt the data by Key-encryption-key (KEK). This function will encrypt your data by a new random key which is encrypted by your AWS cmk. If the data itself is random, non-predictable, non-structural, non-repeat, you MAY use encrypt() for simplicity.

Parameter.description: The data to be encrypted. The data can be in arbitrarily format, the library will do serialization for you.
The id/arn/alias of key in AWS KMS to encrypt to data. If a alias name is supplied, prepend a "alias/", i.e. "alias/my-key".

examples.title: encryptKEK(js/promise)
encryptKEK(ts/async-promise)

Success 200.description: A base64 encoded string contains the encrypted data
A base64 encoded string contains the data key used to encrypt the data. This key is encrypted by your AWS cmk.

examples.title: Cipher-object

title: encrypt
name: encrypt_config
description: Encrypt the data directly though AWS KMS. This function should only be used to encrypt data itself is random, e.g. access token, access secret, etc. If you want to encrypt more predictable data, e.g. user password. Use encryptKEK instead.

Parameter.description: The data to be encrypted. The data can be in arbitrarily format, the library will do serialization for you.
The id/arn/alias of key in AWS KMS to encrypt to data. If a alias name is supplied, prepend a "alias/", i.e. "alias/my-key".

examples.title: encrypt-data(js/promise)
encrypt-data(ts/async-await)
examples.content:
const cipher = await config1.encrypt({ jwtToken: 'abcde12345' });
console.log(cipher);  // "ABase64String"

Success 200.description: A base64 encoded string contains the encrypted data.

description: Alias function for check if the configuration document exists. It do the same as has(undefined, options).

title: get
name: get_config
description: Get one specific config or the whole configuration document

Parameter.description: The type of configuration you are getting, available in typescript

The sub-path to your configuration. The library will resolve your key as object path. If the key containing a ".", you must pass an String[] to enforce your customized path traversal. Skip the parameter or leave undefined will get the whole configuration object
The options to this get configuration request
The core configuration lambda function name
The DynamoDB table name to store all configurations
The document name to get the configurations
Does the library directly access the dynamoDB or invoke aws-lambda-configuration-core.

examples.title: get-single-config-direct(js/promise)
get-whole-config-with-cache(ts/async-await)
path-with-a-dot
with-key
examples.content: "user001"

examples.title: without-key

title: has
name: has_config
description: Check if the configuration exists. It is useful to reduce data transmission between lambdas & database when you only want to check if it exists.

Parameter.description: The sub-path to your configuration. The library will resolve your key as object path. If the key containing a ".", you must pass an String[] to enforce your customized path traversal. Skip the parameter or leave undefined will check if the document exist
The options to this check configuration request
The core configuration lambda function name
The DynamoDB table name to store all configurations
The document name to check the configurations
Does the library directly access the dynamoDB or invoke aws-lambda-configuration-core.

examples.title: has-single-config(js/promise)
has-whole-document(ts/async-await)
examples.content:
const isExist = await config1.has({ documentName: 'tempDocument' });
console.log(isExist); // true

Success 200.description: Does the configuration contains the document / the document contains the path

Parameter.description: The options to construct library. Will override the original default settings
The core configuration lambda function name
The DynamoDB table name to store all configurations
The document name to access the configurations
Customer Master Key (CMK). The id/arn/alias of key in AWS KMS to encrypt to data. If a alias name is supplied, prepend a "alias/", i.e. "alias/my-key".

examples.title: construction(js)
examples.content:
const Config = require('aws-lambda-configuration-js').default;
const config1 = new Config();

examples.title: construction(ts)
examples.content:
import Config from 'aws-lambda-configuration-js';
const config1 = new Config();

examples.title: with-options

Parameter.description: The configuration to store. If key is undefined, this should be an object (unless you really want to store one config per one document). This could happen if you decided to encrypt the whole config document.

The sub-path to your configuration. The library will resolve your key as object path. If the key containing a ".", you must pass an String[] to enforce your customized path traversal. Skip the parameter or leave undefined will create/replace the whole configuration document
The options to this set configuration request
The core configuration lambda function name
The DynamoDB table name to store all configurations
The document name to set the configurations
Does the library directly access the dynamoDB or invoke aws-lambda-configuration-core

create-new-config(ts/async-await)
